text:
KELSEY ALPAIO:
You know that part

at the end of
every episode where
I ask for your career crush?

For this episode, we took one
of your suggestions, museum
curator.

I love museums,
but the last thing

I'm thinking about when
I'm walking through one

is the person who hung
the frame up on the wall,

or the person who
wrote the description
next to the masterpiece.

Turns out that's
actually a good thing.

And I learned that when I
started to dive into what
museum curators actually do.

In this episode I
learned that it's really

about helping artists
bring their ideas
to a general audience.

And although that's a noble
mission, it's not always easy.

This is an extremely
competitive industry,

and a fair salary can
be hard to come by.

But if you're
passionate about art,

and those challenges
don't scare you,

keep watching to
find out if you might
be a good fit for this career.

NATALIE BELL: My
biggest pet peeve

is people who are
walking backwards

while holding their phone
without paying attention
to what's behind them.
Don't do that.
You'll break something.

KELSEY ALPAIO:
That's Natalie Bell.

She's the curator at the
MIT List Visual Arts Center,

a contemporary art museum
in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

So what exactly do
museum curators do?

NATALIE BELL: One way of
thinking about curatorial work
is, OK, you're a midwife.

You're helping an artist
bring something into being.
You're also a translator.

You're maybe taking something
that is primarily visual

and helping put
it into language.

You're also telling
a story and helping

people enter into something
that might be new,

might be difficult,
might be challenging.

But there's a story
to be told there.

And it's your job to make them
interested, and make them care,
give them a reason to care.

KELSEY ALPAIO: As
a museum curator,

what does the
day-to-day look like?

NATALIE BELL: The
day-to-day can really range.

Most days I would
say are desk days,

where I'm doing a lot of
emailing, a lot of planning,

a lot of correspondence
with people.

Conversations with
artists are kind of one
of my favorite parts of any day.

KELSEY ALPAIO: As
you can imagine,

there is a lot that goes
into making an exhibit.

There's overseeing the
transportation of the art.

There's making sure it
gets installed properly.

Of course, there's
making sure that the art
doesn't get damaged.

I wonder what in her mind
makes a good exhibit.

NATALIE BELL: I'm often thinking
about how the exhibition is
laid out, how it's organized.
That's sort of the basic thing.

Oftentimes I'm looking at
who lent the work, where
has this come from.

Oh, wow, they loaned
this from Japan.

Oh, this came from
so-and-so's collection.

Spending a lot of time with the
language around an exhibition.

How are they
interpreting the work?

I also like watching what other
people are doing in the space.

Are they spending lots of
time with a certain thing?
What's catching their attention?

What are they connecting
with, basically?

KELSEY ALPAIO: Natalie began
her career by making art.

But she realized that she
was better at interpreting it

than creating it, which is
what led her to museum work.

NATALIE BELL: I'm not somebody
who studied art history
or studied curating.

I did degrees in
philosophy both times,

which is a little bit
less conventional.

KELSEY ALPAIO: What is
a fair starting salary?

What is typical
in this industry?

And then what should you
actually kind of strive for?

NATALIE BELL: It depends
what city you're in, I think.

The American
Association of Museums

has done a salary survey of the
industry for a number of years.
That's a useful resource.
KELSEY ALPAIO: Got the survey.

Starting from if you're
just entering the field

as a curatorial
assistant, it says

in the low range
is around $25,000,

and in the high range
is around $46,000.

For assistant curator,
low end is $31,000,
high end is $68,000.

And then senior curator, $42,000
is on the low end, $105,000
is on the high end.

And then for chief curator,
which seems like the top dog

here, it's $34,000
on the low end,
and $107,000 on the high end.

How do you live off of
$25,000 in a metropolitan area

or a city where a lot of
these museums are located?

It just doesn't
even seem possible.
And how do you do that?

Internships are an entryway
into the museum world,

and Natalie herself
interned at the New
Museum and the Guggenheim.

NATALIE BELL: I ended
up doing internships
at both places at the same time.

Historically, internships
have been really important
and a valuable stepping stone.

They've also been
really difficult,

I think, for lots of people,
because they've been unpaid.
That's changing now.

I think more people
are committed
to paying their interns.

In my case, I was
waitressing a lot,
and that was my other means.

KELSEY ALPAIO: Unpaid
internships are tricky.

I took one in college, too, and
worked at Old Navy on the side.

You do it for the experience
and for the line on your resume,
and that's the trade-off.

But over the last few years,
ideas around unpaid internships
have changed a lot.

And people are wondering if that
trade-off is really worth it.

Someone who's interested
in this profession

wants to take an
internship, but it's unpaid.

Would you suggest that they
take it for the experience,
or work somewhere else?

NATALIE BELL: You know,
it's a personal choice.
I would say no.

And I wish I had held
the line years ago,
but it was just not--

it was not something that
people did at that time.

And I was really
accustomed to just trying

to make things
work, irregardless
of how difficult it was.

But yeah, it's a
personal choice.

I think it depends on
your own situation.

You might do an internship
where you're just

researching
provenance, or you're

looking at the images
for a catalog that
will be published in two years.

And you're writing artist
biographies for a show
that you'll never get to see.

So internships can
give you some insight

behind the scenes
in an institution,

but you might not really
get hands-on experience
making a show.

What I would caution is
that, in this industry,

starting salaries
can be very low.

And one way that you
get accustomed to that

is by starting out by not
getting any salary at all.

KELSEY ALPAIO: So for
these types of roles,

what do hiring managers
really look for in candidates?
NATALIE BELL: Writing skills.

They look at, as with any job,
a desire, and an interest,

and some evidence
of that commitment.

One thing I've often told people
who are interested in curating

but don't know
how to get a start

is that you don't
have to have a space.

You can curate a show
in your apartment.
I want to make a show.
How can I make a show?
And then make it happen.

Get some friends
together, and paint

the inside of your
parents' garage,

and hang some of
your friends work.

And then it's up to you if
you want to take it further.

Do you want to write a
press release for it?

Do you want to make
a little chat book?

Do you want to invite somebody
from your local paper to come?

All of these things then start
to get your work off the ground

and give you also the
confidence to know

that you have the capacity to
do these things professionally.

KELSEY ALPAIO: This
job can definitely

give you the creative
fulfillment and connection

to art that few
other careers can.

This industry is
far from perfect.

It's a profession where you
really have to love the work,

love what it means, and
love what it can be.

So it sounds like
it was a ton of work

for you to kind of
keep going, to take

these unpaid internships,
to waitress on the side.

What kept you, what motivated
you to stay in this industry?

NATALIE BELL: Because I love
art, and I love artists.

I can't picture
feeling as fulfilled
working in other fields.

I think it just has this
vast capacity for learning.

And I take pleasure in that,
but I also take pleasure

in transmitting that
through making exhibitions,

supporting the work of
artists, and hopefully bringing
that to the public.

KELSEY ALPAIO:
Thanks for watching.
Do you have a career crush?

Tell us about them
in the comments,

and we'll see if we can
talk to them for you.

Subscribe to our channel to
see more interviews with people
actually living the dream.
Bye.
